Pretty panic backtraces inspired by Python's tracebacks. 
  * [ #stacktrace ](https://crates.io/keywords/stacktrace)
  * [ #pretty ](https://crates.io/keywords/pretty)
  * [ #backtrace ](https://crates.io/keywords/backtrace)

  * [ #color ](https://crates.io/keywords/color)

cargo add better-panic
Or add the following line to your Cargo.toml:
better-panic = "0.3.0"

content.raw_markdown:
[](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate better_panicCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/src/better_panic/lib.rs.html#1-574)
Expand description
`better-panic` gives you pretty backtraces for panics.
It is inspired by Python tracebacks and tries to replicate them as well as possible. This is what it looks like:
![](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/raw/master/screenshot.png)
Some of the code is based on the [color-backtrace](https://crates.io/crates/color-backtrace) library.
### [§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#usage)Usage
The most common way to use it is to invoke the `install` function which installs a panic handler. In debug builds the backtrace is shown automatically, in release builds it’s hidden by default.
```
better_panic::install();
```

For more configuration see the `Settings` object.
### [§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#features)Features
  * Colorize backtraces to be easier on the eyes
  * Show source snippets if source files are found on disk
  * Hide all the frames after the panic was already initiated


## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#structs)

[Settings](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/struct.Settings.html "struct better_panic::Settings")
    Configuration for panic printing.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#enums)

[Verbosity](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/enum.Verbosity.html "enum better_panic::Verbosity")
    Defines how verbose the backtrace is supposed to be.
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#functions)

[debug_install](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/fn.debug_install.html "fn better_panic::debug_install")
    Installs the panic handler with debug settings.

[install](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/fn.install.html "fn better_panic::install")
    Installs the panic handler with `Settings::auto`.

# better-panic
[![Build Status](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/workflows/Tests/badge.svg?branch=master)](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/actions?query=workflow%3ATests) [![Crates.io](https://img.shields.io/crates/d/better-panic.svg)](https://crates.io/crates/better-panic) [![License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/mitsuhiko/better-panic)](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/blob/master/LICENSE) [![rustc 1.42.0](https://img.shields.io/badge/rust-1.42%2B-orange.svg)](https://img.shields.io/badge/rust-1.42%2B-orange.svg) [![Documentation](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://docs.rs/better-panic/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/better-panic)
``better-panic`` gives you pretty backtraces for panics.
It is inspired by Python tracebacks and tries to replicate them as well as possible. This is what it looks like:
![](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/800/https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/raw/master/screenshot.png)
Some of the code is based on the [color-backtrace](https://lib.rs/crates/color-backtrace) library.
## Usage
The most common way to use it is to invoke the ``install`` function which installs a panic handler. In debug builds the backtrace is shown automatically, in release builds it's hidden by default.
```
``better_panic`::``install`(``)``;`
`
```

For more configuration see the ``Settings`` object.
## Features
  * Colorize backtraces to be easier on the eyes
  * Show source snippets if source files are found on disk
  * Hide all the frames after the panic was already initiated


## License and Links
  * [Documentation](https://docs.rs/better-panic/)
  * [Issue Tracker](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/issues)
  * [Examples](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/tree/master/examples)
  * License: [MIT](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/blob/master/LICENSE)


#### Dependencies
~2–11MB  ~124K SLoC
  * [backtrace](https://lib.rs/crates/backtrace "0.3.37")
  * [console](https://lib.rs/crates/console "0.15.0")
  * [ optional ](https://lib.rs/crates/better-panic/features#feature-syntect "syntect is optional feature") [syntect](https://lib.rs/crates/syntect "obsolete") 4.6


  *[SLoC]: approx. additional lines of code

advisory.title: safemem is unmaintained
advisory.description:
The latest crates.io release was in 2019. The repository has been archived by the author.

## Migration

- `safemem::copy_over(slice, src_idx, dest_idx, len);` can be replaced with `slice.copy_within(src_idx..src_idx+len, dest_idx);` as of `rust 1.37.0`.
- `safemem::write_bytes(slice, byte);` can be replaced with `slice.fill(byte);` as of `rust 1.50.0`
- `safemem::prepend(slice, vec);` can be replaced with

  ```rust
  let old_len = vec.len();
  vec.extend_from_slice(slice);
  vec.rotate_left(old_len);
  ```
  
  as of `rust 1.26.0`

advisory.title: yaml-rust is unmaintained.
advisory.description:
The maintainer seems [unreachable](https://github.com/chyh1990/yaml-rust/issues/197).

Many issues and pull requests have been submitted over the years
without any [response](https://github.com/chyh1990/yaml-rust/issues/160).

## Alternatives

Consider switching to the actively maintained `yaml-rust2` fork of the original project:

- [yaml-rust2](https://github.com/Ethiraric/yaml-rust2)
- [yaml-rust2 @ crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/yaml-rust2)

crate_analysis.note: Crate analysis performed with stable toolchain.

Help⟨2⟩

It is inspired by Python tracebacks and tries to replicate them as well as possible. This is what it looks like:

  * Colorize backtraces to be easier on the eyes
  * Show source snippets if source files are found on disk
  * Hide all the frames after the panic was already initiated


## Structs§⟨7⟩

Settings⟨8⟩
    Configuration for panic printing.
## Enums§⟨9⟩

Verbosity⟨10⟩
    Defines how verbose the backtrace is supposed to be.
## Functions§⟨11⟩

debug_install⟨12⟩
    Installs the panic handler with debug settings.

install⟨13⟩
    Installs the panic handler with `Settings::auto`.

readme.raw_markdown:
[](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate better_panicCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/src/better_panic/lib.rs.html#1-574)
Expand description
`better-panic` gives you pretty backtraces for panics.
It is inspired by Python tracebacks and tries to replicate them as well as possible. This is what it looks like:
![](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/better-panic/raw/master/screenshot.png)
Some of the code is based on the [color-backtrace](https://crates.io/crates/color-backtrace) library.
### [§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#usage)Usage
The most common way to use it is to invoke the `install` function which installs a panic handler. In debug builds the backtrace is shown automatically, in release builds it’s hidden by default.
```
better_panic::install();
```

For more configuration see the `Settings` object.
### [§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#features)Features
  * Colorize backtraces to be easier on the eyes
  * Show source snippets if source files are found on disk
  * Hide all the frames after the panic was already initiated


## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#structs)

[Settings](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/struct.Settings.html "struct better_panic::Settings")
    Configuration for panic printing.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#enums)

[Verbosity](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/enum.Verbosity.html "enum better_panic::Verbosity")
    Defines how verbose the backtrace is supposed to be.
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/#functions)

[debug_install](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/fn.debug_install.html "fn better_panic::debug_install")
    Installs the panic handler with debug settings.

[install](https://docs.rs/better-panic/latest/better_panic/fn.install.html "fn better_panic::install")
    Installs the panic handler with `Settings::auto`.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `better-panic` crate enhances Rust's panic handling by providing visually appealing, Python-inspired backtraces with colorized output and optional source code snippets. It allows easy installation of a custom panic handler via the `install` function, with automatic behavior adjustments for debug and release builds. Key features include configurable verbosity, hiding irrelevant frames, and improved readability for debugging.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1:
✅ Factual: The `better-panic` crate provides colorized backtraces for panics, making them easier to read and debug.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `better-panic` crate automatically colorizes all console outputs, including `println!` statements, to improve readability.

---

### Pair 2:
✅ Factual: In debug builds, `better-panic` automatically shows backtraces when a panic occurs, while in release builds, backtraces are hidden by default.  
❌ Counterfactual: `better-panic` always shows backtraces regardless of whether the build is in debug or release mode.

---

### Pair 3:
✅ Factual: The `Settings` struct in `better-panic` allows developers to configure verbosity and other aspects of panic backtrace formatting.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `Settings` struct in `better-panic` is used to configure runtime logging levels and output destinations.
